inclusion.criterion: midwife will inform the research team of the mothers' details via a Reply Slip if she has no objection to be contacted.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: criteria for the study (i.e. she has high-risk factors for GDM and is therefore referred for a GTT), but is not given a PIS at the booking visit, the research team will send this out by post to the mother with an invitation letter.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: Feedback from the mothers at the recruitment visit (i.e. dating scan) suggests that the mothers would have been happy to partake in the study at the same visit as receiving the PIS for 4 main reasons: 1) the study (and the PIS) is simple to understand; 2) they spend a significant amount of time awaiting scan and midwife appointment during this visit; 3) they want to have their blood sample taken at the same visit (mothers have a blood test routinely as a standard care); and 4) they prefer not to come back for a separate visit.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: The participants will have basic demographic information collected and anthropometric measurements done during the recruitment visit and be asked to fill out physical activity and psychological well-being questionnaires.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: Mothers will have their OGTT at 24-28 weeks gestation and further blood, urine and stool (optional) samples will be taken at this time for study purposes.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: The remainder of a participant's antenatal care will then carry on in the joint antenatal-diabetes clinic (if she has been diagnosed with GDM) or in the community (for non-GDM mothers, unless she has any other indication to be referred to the obstetric clinic).
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: All the participants will have their deliveries in one of the NHS Hospitals involved in the study.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: Cord blood, a piece of cord and placental biopsies (around 2cm each) will be taken at the time of birth as well as detailed birth and neonatal outcome data and a stool sample from the baby shortly afterwards.
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: Baby's body fat content and distribution will be measured by the 'PEAPOD' machine. This is a non invasive, baby friendly way of accurately measuring the fat distribution in the baby.
inclusion.label: unknown

exclusion.criterion: Diagnosis of B12 or folate deficiency in the current pregnancy
exclusion.label: unknown

exclusion.criterion: Vitamin B12 injections in the previous 6 months
exclusion.label: does_not_trigger

notes: The patient is a 41-year-old obese woman coming to the emergency room with abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain that started gradually yesterday is located in the epigastric and periumbilical regions, radiating to her back.
